Predators is a pretty good action movie for about 45 minutes. Unfortunately, it lasts 106.
Right from its memorable opening... Predators is an adrenaline rush.
What it lacks in imagination, it makes up in execution. It fulfills its limited potential, which is more than can be said of most of this summer's movies.
Predators is a movie you love if it's your thing. Key word: if. It's not mine.
to say that it is the best of the Predator sequels is little more than faint praise
It's no "Aliens", but it does have an intriguing setup, good pace and a surprisingly action-ready Adrien Brody.
An obvious improvement over the two Alien vs. Predator movies...
Nothing can disguise the fact that it's ... contrived, chaotic and ultimately pointless
If you don't know the original 1987 classic Predator line-for-line and inside-out, you will probably miss half the gags in this one.
full review at Movies for the Masses
Predators never overcomes the fatal miscasting of Brody as the group's take-charge, tough-guy leader.
Innocent but skillful.
Though too reverent of the original Predator, this is a respectable entry into the franchise regardless.
Stonewall Uprising deploys familiar PSA-cum-hate-crimes like the infamous "Boys Beware" with very little restraint in order to truly establish Stonewall's prehistory as a No M2M's Land.
It's after the riots that the real show begins.
An insightful and moving documentary.
The story of how, in 1969, gays and lesbians fought the cops at Greenwich Village's Stonewall Inn ... is told thoroughly but without much passion, humor, rowdiness, or smut.
Stonewall Uprising is first and foremost about people. Politics and history and sexuality are there, too, but they're subsidiary to the human stories the documentary tells.
Stonewall Uprising is an important documentary -- and a passionate and compassionate reconstruction of the historic standoff between police and pubcrawlers.
Excellent source of information for those who know little of this monumental occurrence, but for those with no need for a Stonewall riots 101, it has little to offer.
The Oath does give the viewer something to think about, but the film is unsatisfying, raising questions and providing too few answers.
A documentary that at its start purports to be the tale of two terrorists, the film keeps deepening and widening until it becomes a subtle, stubborn moral drama about users and the used.
Compelling both as drama and as an indictment of the eight years of folly known as the War on Terror.

The Oath makes spare use of images to convey a great deal. Al-Bahri's smiling child is surrounded by lethal weapons that are little more than toys to him. The color-drained skies of Guantnamo are juxtaposed with the lively Yemeni street scenes.
Poitras has crafted an extremely savvy and compelling documentary, an essential piece of the increasingly intricate puzzle that is the war on terror.
First-time feature filmmaker Alexandre Franchi shoots the outdoors amazingly claustrophobically - an almost-oxymoric effect that contributes to the unsettling atmosphere of The Wild Hunt.

Nice performances, interesting ideas and intriguing visuals aside, the final product is as cold as the environment its set in, and as such my medieval instincts are to urge people to ultimately leave this particular picture alone.
Even if Dudley Moore's performance weren't so darn funny, it would still be worth watching just for John Gielgud.
It's the movie we'll forever know Dudley Moore for -- and the late John Gielgud, too, who is put out to pasture about halfway through this classic comedy.
Only someone with a heart of stone could fail to love a drunk like Arthur Bach.
...suffers from a hit-and-miss quality that wreaks havoc on its momentum...
An intriguing if uneven documentary...
Entertaining, insightful, and moving.
John Carpenter's third movie (two years before Halloween), and one of his best.
Rough, raw, and entirely unapologetic action classic.
This early Carpenter movie still holds up as one of the director's best works.
In Assault On Precinct 13, hell is an abandoned police station in Los Angeles and the only means of survival is cooperation across racial, class, and legal lines.
Perhaps Carpenter's best film next to The Thing, this is a model of low-budget filmmaking, with a tight script, appropriately tight-lipped actors and atmospheric location shooting.
...a seriously erratic early effort from an otherwise masterful filmmaker.
A great little gothic horror anthology. Track this one down if you can!
Asylum tries telling similar tales (twice) and comes up pathetically short in the scare department.
not as good as monster club, but still quite interesting
One of the best anthology horror films ever made
Hanna and Juran make up for their lack of supernatural thrills by packing lots of talking, fighting, dancing and drinking -- as well as a few lame jokes -- into the movie's harmless 65 minutes.
...has little to offer even the most ardent fan of trash cinema.
Should've been a fun cheesy movie, but every time it actually TRIES to be funny, it wasn't funny. The movie is uneven.
Dry-as-dust "possession" fare.

Twenty-four years after he freed the Israelites, Charlton Heston returned to Egypt to insult the ancient gods again in 'The Awakening.' Let my people go -- to their Netflix queues, to request the erratic but more enjoyable 'Blood from the Mummy's Tomb.'
An easy watch, except for the annoying demeanour of its lead character.
A naturalistic, irreverent and sometimes broadly comic view of a largely ignored aspect of the Civil War gives Bad Company a refreshingly good name.
[A] smart, character-driven Western that plays a little like the undercover cop genre.
While lesser sports comedies have tried to mimic the humour and sloppy charm of The Bad News Bears, none have even come close.
Matthau's perfectly restrained, brilliantly comic performance holds it together.
This charming, funny film takes a gentle poke at Little League baseball and the American obsession with winning.
If all kids' movies were like this, you wouldn't need to drag parents to the multiplexes.
Stagy pacing and a few woeful missteps can't change the fact that this is a creepified horror classic.
The Bad Seed reflects Slant Magazine's blind, abject terror of precocious, well-behaved little blonde girls.
Wrung to the point of unwatchable by meandering monologues and slow reveals.
Unfortunately, no real relationships are ever developed in this film, so, even with Robert DeNiro playing the lead, something always seems to be lacking.
A well-done if depressing film.
Mention this flick to any guy over 40 and watch him get all weepy.
Even though it's forty-five years old is it as poignant and relevant today as it was back in the 1970s. It's worth watching for any young person, especially those involved in sports.
One of the best films to depict World War II to be made by people who experienced it.
A work of magic that makes the Broadway adaptation look like overproduced swill.

critic_name: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone
review_content: The restoration of this 1946 film is a beauty, but I'm just not sure this beast of a movie is worth the trouble.
This version of the familiar fairy tale has long been revered for its dreamlike state, which continues to mesmerize even in this age of $100 million computer-generated effects.
Littering his film with wonderfully evocative shots of steam rising off of the simmering Beast, Jean Cocteau accentuates his seething animal intensity.
This film is such a visual delight that I gave up worrying about ideological considerations and just embraced its beautiful and influential dreamlike imagery.
Cocteau's enduring fable remains just as enchanting and charming as it ever was.
The third act...is a near riot of action, climaxing with a restaging of the "Zulu Wars" in the crowded halls of a tumbledown manor house turned boarding school for girls.
...a special little film that's well worth seeking out.
Hamer brings his visual wit to lives of Norwegian precision
In the end, Bent Hamer's view of current international relations comes to down to a treacly rendition of "Kumbaya."
Double the Tomlin & Midler cannot save silly doppelganger gimmickry.

an oddity of incessant proportions, a comedy with few laughs but many unwarranted chuckles, which lives and dies on the notion its silly premise will at least be vague enough to provide its actors with great opportunities to improvise.
Perfectly suited to film noir fans who like their stories dark, their characters dark, and their heroes decent but morally tested.
Relentlessly depressing and cynical, and although it was well-made, its cruelty made it an uncomfortable experience.
For those who take their film black...Moral rot gets full play in Lang's 1953 police drama. [Blu-ray]
Great dialogue, atmosphere and performances by Humphrey Bogart, Lauren Bacall and others.
A movie that every film student should study and every movie lover should watch at least once.

There's little else I can add about this proto-noir, one of the archetypes of the genre and a showstopper for Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart, who spar through a catty romance while dancing through a taut mystery.
It matters not that even the writers (including William Faulkner) weren't sure who shot whom in Hawks' rousing adaptation of the Raymond Chandler detective novel.
The movie feels kind of embalmed.
The Birds is an effective horror movie, although in typical Hitchcock style, there is far more scary anticipation than actual gore.
Only Alfred Hitchcock could take a premise which is so patently ridiculous -- the birds come to life and try to kill everybody -- and construct a beautifully realized thriller.
The Birds is most notable though for turning something completely harmless into an incredible menace -- all with absolutely no explanation.
The only thing dated is the special effects. The suspense holds up very well.
In the thick of an impeccable narrative that pays deep attention to all those involved, the great filmmaker manages to reach far inside the psychological chasm and find a rich inspiration.

...a sporadically effective slasher...
Something less fun than the worst exploitation sci-fl flick thrown at us by the likes of Roger Corman.
Disney's first PG-rated film was pioneering for its time (integrating special effects better than any film before it), but it suffers pretty badly today.
Even as a fantasy-lovin' boy of 14, I was bored silly by this movie, and a repeat viewing just last week revealed that the film has, if anything, gotten worse over time.
It's not as campy as the Airport flicks, nor as thrilling as James Bond, but taken as a sort of combo between the two, you could certainly do a lot worse.
Since its protagonists are anti-heroic and its antagonists are admirable, it will be hard for audiences to identify with segments of the movie.
The acting is good -- especially from Dern in his over-the-top mode -- and parts of the film are exciting. But I draw the line at finding it to be any sort of a classic.
Black Widow is an interesting movie struggling to escape from a fatal overload of commercial considerations.
Surprises are few and far between in this attractively filmed yet disappointingly conventional thriller that's short on psychological heft.
Horrific and dated....worth seeing from a strictly historical standpoint.
This is the kind of movie that serves as a reminder that comedy is agonizingly difficult when it works, and even more trouble when it doesn't.
[Settles] into the quick-react rhythm of modern sitcoms.
A sex farce with flat characters trapped within '80s sensibilities...
This is something special, even among its ilk. Frighteningly bad.
Unfortunately, while it certainly broke new ground in terms of explicit gore, it isn't a very good film.
Intriguing for its glimpses of backstage life in shabby German postwar vaudeville, and for Dietrich's performance.
...part exploitation piece, part morality tale.
A pretty entertaining film.
Perhaps as a whole, Born Yesterday isn't the equal of All About Eve or Sunset Boulevard, but I would put Holliday right up there with Davis and Swanson for her performance here.
An intriguing and underrated film with a great deal to say.
Despite its flaws, this is a film that looks great, includes a memorable Hopkins performance, and is well enough written to keep us thinking rather than latching onto stereotypes.
South America is turned into a virtual sci-fi lab for the creation of ninety-four versions of the Der Fuhrer in Franklin J. Schaffner's campy The Boys From Brazil.
...given the caliber of the cast and crew, it should have been a whole lot better.
Fast-paced, gripping and totally ludicrous.
This is a terrifically chilling entertainment, one that deserves a spot alongside the best paranoid thrillers of the 1970s.
A film too dopey and campy to be taken seriously, too mordant and sober to be much fun, and too ludicrous and melodramatic to be at all defensible as a social commentary.
...it's Bronson's performance that keeps things interesting even during some of the more superfluous sequences...
Pryor appears to self-delete expletives in Brewster's Millions by making a litany of far more offensive Stepin Fetchit facial expressions.
A simplistic remake of an oft-told tale. Pryor does PG like porn stars do Shakespeare.
An uncommonly good little picture -- and one which is frankly designed to appeal to that group of film-goers who are provoked by the 'usual movie tripe.'
Tremendously downbeat, but beautifully stylized.
Progressive for its day, but strictly of historic value today.
There is so much that is unusually excellent and excellently unusual in Broken Blossoms that one is compelled by enthusiasm to write about it.
The most elemental and uncluttered of D.W. Griffith's major melodramas.
This is the ultimate Paul Newman - Robert Redford movie. The two are charismatic, good-looking, smart and funny.

Although Butch Cassidy wasn't the first movie to pair up a couple of wisecracking best friends in an action/adventure setting, this film became the model of how well that approach could work when done right.
William Goldman's script is constantly too cute and never gets up the nerve, by God, to admit it's a Western.
Possibly the most likable movie ever filmed.
Looking at the film with a totally modern set of eyes, completely detached from the hype of Newman and Redford in the late 60s, I didn't find a connection to the movie.
Although much of its freshness has faded, this still-amusing film reinvented the Western for a new generation.
Of all the innocent and innocuous musicals of the 1960's, this goofy one is my favorite.

Innocent-yet-sexy Ann-Margret is perfectly cast as the teenybopper, Van Dyke is winning in one of his few lead feature film roles, and Paul Lynde hilariously conveys a father's inability to understand teenagers and rock music.
Neither great, nor perhaps even very good, the film remains a charming artifact.
Miss Garbo has interpreted Marguerite Gautier with the subtlety that has earned for her the title, 'first lady of the screen.'
The first half is a bit slow and occasionally corny, but the second half, where Marguerite finds herself forced to make decisions instead of coyly putting them off, really picks up.
works best as a twisted nail-biter, punctuated brilliantly with an apocalyptic score by Bernard Herrmann
Rousing swashbuckling of the variety that you don't see much anymore.
can verge on adventure overkill
Back then, Warner Brothers sure knew how to make these adventures a great time at the movies and today, "Captain Blood" is immensely captivating.

With a spirited and criminally good-looking Australian named Errol Flynn playing the genteel buccaneer to the hilt, the photoplay recaptures the air of high romantic adventure which is so essential to the tale.
Well-directed, well-acted coming-of-age tale that may have the most hard-bitten viewer in tears by the end.
Bartholomew's transition from evil brat to nice kid is so subtle that it's surprising when you notice it.
An unlikely love story of two opposites splendidly directed by Fleming.
If that's a Portuguese accent Tracy is sporting, then I'm Katharine Hepburn -- if anything, his performance appears to be based on Chico Marx. Nevertheless, this is top-notch entertainment.
A nightmarish puzzle. It's aged very well.
demonstrates that the quality of scary filmmaking is not directly proportional to the size of the budget
A chilling ghost story with artistic pretensions.

One of those unique horror movies where the low budget, gritty footage and rough performances combine to create not only an unsettling atmosphere of dread but also a study of existential angst in the face of unimaginable horror.
A bold film that plays like a perfect nightmare for everyone who's used to standard structures in genre cinema. Still scary after decades. [Full review in Spanish].
Horror in the classic sense, horror that builds rather than constantly shocking, horror that works so well we don't need a guts and gore booster-shot every two minutes.
Brian De Palma's Carrie is an absolutely spellbinding horror movie... It's also (and this is what makes it so good) an observant human portrait.

The film has a strikingly unsettling mood that enhances its power and gives it an impact that the story would otherwise lack. Much of the credit, though, must go to Spacek, who so convincingly portrays Carrie's pain and her longing for acceptance.

I might be the only person in the world who thinks Brian De Palma's 1976 classic thriller Carrie (now out on DVD) is one of the most overrated, disappointing horror films of all time, but I stand behind my review, and I swear I can knock down just about a
Carrie is one of the most heart-breaking and cringe-worthy high school dramas ever made, and that's before she even gets to her apocalyptic revenge.
A voluptuously shot horror movie.

Like Jaws, here's one of those rare instances when the movie is better than the book. What's more, this box office hit easily remains the best adaptation of a King property (sorry, Shawshank and Shining groupies).
A film for anyone who has ever had a heartbreaking choice to make, for film lovers who enjoy unpredictable endings, and for anyone who has lost a love.
The greatest pleasure anyone can derive from this movie comes through simply watching it.
Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman are pure magic in one of the most romantic films ever. [Full review in Spanish]
Note to filmmakers: If you want to spoof something, at least make sure you're outdoing your source material on the comedy front.
There is a razor thin line between being funny and being stupid.
It may, in fact, be the first post-modern comedy, but it feels more good-natured than snarky -- and there's an undercurrent of true British satire here.
Profoundly unamusing bore.

Proponents of this dreadfully indulgent cabaret, which thumbs its nose at coherence, have called its nigh-impenetrable plot the sincerest form of satire. That's like citing the indecipherable nature of Zapf Dingbats as a foremost send-up of language.
The sort of creepy movie that is perhaps best thought of as spooky fun -- and 85 years have not changed that.
Not exactly a horror film, at least by any strict definition. But it is a great deal of fun.

Elizabeth Taylor and Paul Newman, both gorgeous beyond measure, strike sparks as the sexually unfulfilled Maggie and her tortured husband Brick, while Burl Ives is sensational as the family patriarch Big Daddy.
The way it messes with your head -- and Jacques Tourneur's deft ability behind the camera -- make it quite the '40s standout.
Handled more with shadow and suggestion than the outright statement found in the horror pictures that surrounded it.
...a startling, psychosexual horror picture - especially for its time.
One of the most sexually and psychologically astute films of its time, tackling female sexuality in a way that was unheard of at the time.

Cat People is rife with subversive subtexts, alarming suggestions, and potent performances. Cinema rarely manages something so creepy and bizarre as Tourneur and Lewton's strangely poignant and unforgettable film.
nothing if not interesting, and it has several sequences that are genuinely electrifying and audacious
Lumbering but titillating.
The emotional arousal of the original is replaced with sexual arousal and what we have is an erotic gorefest that should not have been made.

Cat People is a good movie in an old tradition, a fantasy-horror film that takes itself just seriously enough to work, has just enough fun to be entertaining, [and] contains elements of intrinsic fascination in its magnificent black leopards.
Ludicrous or not, Cat People is gorgeous to behold, due mostly to cinematographer John Bailey's marvelous detailed rendering of New Orleans in autumn.
...an art-house experiment gone horribly wrong.
A twisted, sexy horror classic.
An appropriately strange beast-part moody, sex-saturated art film, and part slick genre fare.

The most offputting thing about such canny, tear-stained movies as The Champ is not their navet but their unholy sophistication. These movies don't mean to deal with the world as it really is, but as it should be.
The original film took 85 minutes, this one 121; the extra length has not improved the story.
Robson's direction is all action, wasting no time in telling this compelling story, and Carl Foreman's script is sharply observant of the boxing milieu.
There are only a couple of action scenes and they're okay, but the real joy is definitely from watching Hepburn and Grant together.
Sparkles with all the vigor of freshly uncorked champagne.
even though the age difference is kinda weird the romance works
E.B. White's affecting tale is given a Saturday morning cartoon treatment.
Almost as sweet as the children's classic novel, "Charlotte's Web" is just, well, crawling with entertainment.
It's fair to say that the best stuff comes directly from E.B. White's plot and prose.
Considering the sprawling cast of distinctive characters and personalities, The Chase remains a compact exercise in control.
"plenty of corn, for sure, but no chills"
incredibly boring from start to finish
It's a--look, it has to be said--corny "B" horror flick with a certain je ne sais WTF about it. [Blu-ray]
its dated look reminds us that horror movies were once made with only a camera and buckets of Karo syrup; not marketable teen models and computer-generated effects.
The Chosen never came alive for me. I respected what the filmmakers were trying to do, and I admired the ambitious period production, but I never really cared about these people.
Most viewers will still remember other versions of the film more readily, but this is one worth seeking out 'round holiday time.
A great and eternally heart-warming film that can stand an appreciative viewing every year through every decade.
reasonably good fun, and Stanwyck actually overcomes the role's limitations
Peter Godfrey, the director, has a good deal to learn about the art of telling a boudoir joke in the parlor and getting away with it.
A sometimes hilarious farce and a holiday favorite.
A delightful movie.
[It has] emerged over the past two decades as second only to It's a Wonderful Life as the definitive Christmas flick.
If you're a fan of Christmas movies or films that use nostalgia as a driver, A Christmas Story cannot be missed. Then again, if you're in either category, you have probably already seen it.
This great heartwarming comedy from the director of Porky's was a flop during its theatrical run, but, like It's a Wonderful Life, has become a staple on cable during the holiday season.
[A] richly remembered tale of Christmas past.
For pure history, this is a must, but it's laughable at times because of its overwrought machismo and intense over-acting.
Consistently dull, this old western tale is highlighted by an endearing debut performance by Irene Dunne.
It holds up surprisingly well today.
The all-time worst winner of the Academy Award for Best Picture.
It's asp-tastic.
A giant white elephant of a movie, a bloated monument to hubris and excess.
The movie is also dotted with some battle sequences of nearly epic proportions, but they can't make up for Cleopatra's shortcomings in plot and acting.
This is not a film -- it's a deal, decorated with extensive publicity, but weighed down by listless direction and lots of nasal talk, talk, talk.
A lumbering monstrosity of a movie with all manner of preposterous hairstyles and improbable fashions. Worth seeing -- once anyway -- at least as wayward legend.
...a tale of two men being manipulated, and possibly loved, by a powerful and conflicted woman.
The movie is worth seeing for a lot of reasons, one of them being the weirdly elegant pratfall Keaton takes on the baseball diamond when he gets clipped by an opposing player sliding into third.
Keaton helped write the textbook on comedy, and in College he gives us a master class.
Running a brisk 65 minutes, College is sparse on story, heavy on gags. Keaton knew how to get straight to the good stuff.
Though its story has the makings of standard stuff, and is sometimes sketchily told, nothing about 'Colors is ordinary.
What is there to write about a lacklustre gang-related film that wants to be more than it amounts to?
Colors has a tentative, ambivalent feel to it--as if Hopper merely considered himself a hired gun who should avoid imposing too personal a vision on the material.
Coma wastes a superb performance by Bujold on a simplistic, predictable series of cliched suspense scenes, seasoned with some last-minute moralizing about contemporary medicine.
Filmmaker Michael Crichton does an effective job of immediately capturing the viewer's interest and attention...
Mindless bullet-ridden fun all the way.
For action fans, one of the picks of the litter for the year.
An audacious comic-book movie on steroids...cinematic junk food, but even a dieter deserves to cheat once in a while. [Blu-Ray]
It might have been fun to watch when I was nine, but knowing what I know now, it is a horribly offensive film.
Two of Hollywood's greatest stars give what might be their best performances.
If you enjoy Crosby as a crooner instead of a showman, this is your movie.
This is still a decent movie and a good example of the monster movie genre.
As directed by Jack Arnold, the film suffers from silly stretches of dialogue and wooden acting, but the underwater footage is still beautiful, and Adams radiates a strong, sexy screen presence.
Very neat
When I was a kid, this was the movie monster I wanted to be.

Crossroads borrows so freely and is a reminder of so many other movies that it's a little startling, at the end, to realize how effective the movie is and how original it manages to feel despite all the plunderings.
Any music fan will do well spend an hour and a half watching this one.
A D-grade slasher flick that has delusions of comedy and mystery, of interest only to those who lust after Brad Pitt and would love to check out a performance the actor would probably rather forget.
It's that guilty pleasure you really won't admit you've experienced...
Why did and does Hollywood continue to put non-singers in musicals? No one in this movie has a good voice.
Probably the best adaptation of the celebrated novel you can find.

Stephen Frears' direction is superb -- the design and lighting evoke simultaneous worlds of privilege and squalor, and while the nature of day-to-day life in 18th century France becomes readily apparent, it never becomes distracting.
John Schlesinger's Darling is a film of excessive and self-defeating brilliance.
Maybe Romero, whose original movie was a genuine inspiration, hasn't figured out anything new to do with his zombies.
Say what you will about Romero, but he's never sold out on this series.
The most flawed in the series, but also the most ambitious.
An indisputable classic.

Demonstrates you don't need to be bombed back into the stone age when you can reach that state by exercising your own stupidity. The subterranean setting is the tip-off: While the zombies evolve the humans devolve -- almost literally -- into cave men.
Next time your parents tell you that they don't make them like they used to, believe them.
A true 1950s drive-in classic.
Long considered a touchstone in science fiction cinema, this stood apart from most of the other 50s sci-fi outings for many reasons.

It is comforting, of course, to have it made plain that our planetary neighbors are much wiser and more peaceful than are we, but this makes for a tepid entertainment in what is anamolously labeled the science-fiction field.
The most amazing thing about this excellent film is how well it has held up and how its message is just as true today as it was in the immediate post-Second World War years.
...dispels any notion you might have about shlocky science fiction.
Iconic from the get-go.
Lemmon has given a sizable number of terrific performances over his career, and this one qualifies as a Top 10 entry. As for Remick, she's never been better.
Despite the overwhelming demand for Treat Williams/Joe Piscopo team-ups, this effort remains surprisingly hard to find.
On the screen, it seems to be like a walking corpse itself: jerking around malevolently, with putrefying limbs, a fixed, grisly smile on its face and absolutely no spontaneity.
Despite the omissions from Mann's text, dependence on flashbacks, and overwrought arguments about art and music between Aschenbach and a colleague, it remains a film of great beauty.
Bogarde plays Gustav with a hamfist, practically drooling over the kid he's stalking
Visconti's self-conscious and self-reflexive artistry can be off-putting, but with Death in Venice, he's crafted a sumptuous feast for the senses.
A sumptuous visual feast, a well-told tale of a tortured artist's sturm und drung.
Visconti's mastery of visual style almost succeeds in creating the very ideas and feelings that his heavy-handed narrative entirely misses.
Feels like a very good, very entertaining movie, but Grand Hotel feels like something truly special. However, the good in Dinner at Eight is very good indeed.
A sparkling script and game efforts from an all-star cast easily overcome the creakiness.
Lean's mastery of the epic form makes up for a weak central love story
Beautiful cinematography...and set design...together with excellent performances combine to form Zhivago's timeless appeal

Dodge City spirited Errol Flynn away from his swashbuckling milieu and into a Wild West setting, and the match proved so natural that the Australian actor found himself cast in several more sagebrush sagas over the ensuing years.
Stuart Gordon's "Dolls" features some neat special effects and makeup, but they're not nearly enough to make up for the film's lack of material and sluggish pacing.
The silly concept (killer dolls!) manages to work because [the special effects] are so solid.
...a fairly straight-forward premise that's executed to watchable yet erratic effect...
Unable to explore the disturbingly misogynist undercurrents of the tale, the film is memorable mostly for the fine performances of the leads.
Easily the best of the many versions of the Stevenson horror classic.
While some of the dialogue and acting may now seem arch, this remains a standout take on the classic novel, visually inventive and often surprisingly strong given the era in which it was made.
Its brightness, cleanness, tightness, and wit all go in to making it feel as fresh and alive as any other piece of animation from its generation.
Bathed in an atmosphere of nightmare, dread and otherworldliness that is unlike anything else in American horror cinema.
Dracula takes place within the confines of the parlors and drawing rooms of London society, which bears a striking resemblance to Americana circa 1931.
there is a reason why Bela ended up in Ed Wood movies
Lugosi's seminal performance and the striking opening act are what distinguish Browning's version of the classic tale.
Just doesn't fly.
The casting is right on target and the atmosphere fittingly eerie in director John Badham's suspenseful, handsomely-mounted 1979 version.
Several horror scenes, notably those not involving Dracula himself, are genuinely creepy.
One of the worst of all straightforward versions of the venerable Bram Stoker tale.
It simply doesn't come off, and the viewer will be left with an empty feeling, a vacuous notion that somehow the laugh scenes slipped by unnoticed. They were never really there.
Dan Aykroyd steals the show with a hilarious impersonation and tribute to the stern-faced TV cop Joe Friday, played for more than a decade by Jack Webb.

At one time, maybe Dan Aykroyd's accelerated, authoritative jibber-jabber caroming off Tom Hanks' loud wailing was enough. But today, "Dragnet" feels pokey next to the peers of based-on-TV-series sorta-parodies it helped inspire.
Yet another Keaton-related disaster. Get this guy a new agent!
The Dream Team ultimately fares best in its affable and consistently watchable first half...
Brian De Palma is truly a great filmmaker. Whether you enjoy his work or hate his guts, you got to admit that he's at least brilliant at crafting impressive set pieces.
It will keep your interest, at least -- if nothing else, it'll remind you that 1980 was really an extension of the overblown 1970s.
All dressed up with no script to go, but a feverish nerve jangler nonetheless.
Eerily transcendent, Dressed to Kill is a layered machine of on-target character work and the sort of tension that only the best of the best filmmakers can ratchet.

A lurid film featuring throat-slashing, overheated lust, and a too-simple reduction of cross-dressing issues for pulpy purposes. But it also uses grand cinematic gestures to relay the dread and guilt of its characters to great effect.
Duel has come to represent much of what is "wrong" with the current cinema.
A sign of great things yet to come.
...a surprisingly sturdy first effort for a filmmaker who would (obviously) go onto bigger and better things.
Dune re-announces itself as a movie to remember. Whether that makes for good memories or bad depends on your tolerance for gonzo cinema.
If you think David Lynch is the Kwisatz Haderach, baby, have I got a movie for you.
Now, in a far less Star Wars saturated landscape, Dune can be viewed as what it is: a brilliant mistake, misguided from the start but still aesthetically satisfying.
Crafted with meticulous precision and infinite patience, the film unfolds like a good novel, with compelling exposition eventually giving way to thrilling action.
In short, there is energy and intensity but little clarity and emotion in this film. It is like a great, green iceberg: mammoth and imposing but very cold.
Overwrought, often splendid Kazan version of the Steinbeck novel. The movie's chief distinction is the amazing debut of rebellious, romantic James Dean.
as exciting a drama as you're ever likely to see, and ultimately it's the unforgettable Dean that makes it so
If you turn the sound down on East of Eden (and, by all means, do), you'll see why Dean is a legend.
What could be a better way to spend two hours?
a reaction to our plutocracy's values and a further case for Dean as the sainted figure of rebellion that would fuel the generational schism of the '60s.
After testing various performers (including a newcomer named Paul Newman), Kazan went with the unknown Dean, a move that immediately yielded dividends.
James Dean is decidedly the highlight of the film. His Method acting techniques and uninhibited performing style cause him to stand out among the more conventional cast.

If you are not a Dangerfield fan, of course, probably nothing on earth could induce you to go to this movie. The great Dangerfield movie, however, has still to be made. This one doesn't get quite enough respect.
it's Dangerfield's emergence as a certified movie star that makes this movie worth investigating
While it's ultimately a hit-and-miss affair, it boasts enough clever bits (particularly during the first half) to make it worthwhile.
will always be more of a curiosity piece than a truly satisfying movie in and of itself
Attained a certain level of cult classic status.
Slow-moving, sensual, and often gorgeous to behold.
Pasolini's rather straightforward style does occasionally mute the film's emotional impact.
Avoids the obvious traps of simple romanticism and playing into sheer pity for Merrick's noble plight.
Beautifully acted and photographed in absolutely gorgeous wide-screen black-and-white, the results are rarely less than stunning, despite the lapses into the melodramatic.
The Elephant Man is a memorable film about human survival and a powerful commentary on human exploitation.
This black-and-white film already includes several Lyncian benchmarks: hissing noises, nightmare sequences, and moments of deadly quiet.
Has the look and texture of an authentic document, elevated by the hand of a artist with a singular vision
Following his startling debut with Eraserhead, David Lynch retained that picture's industrial imagery, unnerving sound design, and oddball atmosphere and layered them over this rich story.
When the final credits roll, you can be forgiven a vague sense of dissatisfaction, because the creativity that went into formulating the premise was never extended to the script writing stage.
This isn't a brazenly colourful futuristic landscape but a grimy portrait of a city not far from the down-and-dirty real New York of the late '70s and early '80s.
I love this movie, yet I'm not sure if I respect it.
The oppressive power of Carpenter's Scope framing is matched only by his ability to speak to contemporary affairs.
Vicious scenes are often juxtaposed with comic sequences in a tap dance of contrasting tones that is both bizarre and grandly entertaining.
It's a toughly told, very tall tale, one of the best escape (and escapist) movies of the season.
Reagen-era horseshit.

Most of the images are elaborate confections of urban blight, etched against a nearly unlit soundstage, and the sound mix, until the finale, is rarely louder than Snake's elbow busting out an old windowpane.

Snake is Carpenter's fantasy alter ego, a man of uncompromised anti-authoritarianism. 'I don't give a f--- about your war, or your President,' Snake tells the police commissioner, voicing a sentiment that was hardly unusual during Carpenter's USC days.

Peter Yates' initially promising thriller becomes a turgid trifle that wastes its '40s-noir-in-'80s-fashion premise. The only thing more anemic than its mystery or social commentary? Hurt and Weaver's sexual chemistry. Film at 11, asleep by 11:30.
It's a totally intelligent film with a great message, wonderfully presented by Truffaut, with the upmost competence.
This is how you adapt a literary classic to the big screen.
Those looking for a tight thriller will be bored; those looking for effective horror will be annoyed.

Many of the risible moments come courtesy of the scenes in which stage star Sally Ross (Bacall) is preparing for a new musical -- the glimpses we see of the kitschy show designate it as the unholy lovechild between 1980's Xanadu and 1983's Staying Alive.
This is a predictable story that Schlesinger struggles to keep fresh and moving.
Because the good things in the movie -- including the performances -- are so very good, it's a shame that the film's potential for greatness was so blatantly compromised.
Sure, Alex may be little more than a bunny-boiling stalker but Fatal Attraction is still notable for Close's resilient, complex performance.
Overflowing with artistic flair and piercing sexuality, director Adrian Lyne's Fatal Attraction is a psychological horror film that dwells on reality instead of fantasy.
See website for more details.
Solid direction, ,thrilling set pieces, and an iconic performance from Glenn Close. It's a sleazy movie, but an extremely watchable one. The entertainment value for this one is very high.
Until it goes berserk in the last reel or so, Fatal Attraction is an absorbing drama of civilized adultery that gets less civilized as it goes on to its inevitable conclusion.
There are so many reasons Fatal Attraction is such a great film but first and foremost is the cast.
Fatal Attraction may remain an influence on the genre but something could be said about the depiction of mental health in the film.
If you feel like camping it up, then rent this one.
a total bomb; an insult to the original serials; not even good camp.
If only Ming the Merciless had turned his death ray on the producers...

I'm guessing nine out of ten people would rather watch the bearded, barrel-shaped Blessed--strapped to giant wings--bellow, 'Impetuous boy! Oh well, who wants to live forever? Diiiive!' than watch Olivier deliver 'To be or not to be...' [Blu-ray]
While it's not the best of the sci-fi genre, you don't have to go to a galaxy far, far away to enjoy every minute of it.
A lot more entertaining than first looks would indicate. Plus it's always fun to laugh at the 1980s.
For all its flaws this remains an intriguing early work by a highly capable director that proves you don't need a big budget to tell an epic tale.
A smart character study disguised as a thriller, and well worth viewing.
a sunny windswept antidote to endless helpings of frantic Japanimation
Fun, slightly campy film.
Fun and frightening.
The Fly is a study in how the boldness of new discoveries is compromised by science's need for precision, but it's also a nightmarish tale of a comfortable little family, and a nagging little buzz.
It's gross, scary and well made.
Instead of being a pretty good cautionary fable about the limits of technology, it's a show-and-tell in fifth grade biology.
Where other Cronenberg films have collapsed under the heavy weight of their own ideas ... The Fly succeeds.

The remake opts for a slow metamorphosis from man to fly that develops as a disease might. This gives Cronenberg time to examine the implications of such a process, meditating upon our fear of disease, death and change.
The Fly is almost unique for a horror movie in that it compels us sympathize with and root for the characters.
For all its fetishistic attention to gross-out elements, what primarily distinguishes the film is its love story.
One could take it as a quaint little throwback, if the movie weren't so tedious.
Footloose is a seriously confused movie that tries to do three things, and does all of them badly.
reignited the youth genre with the dynamics of music video aesthetics and has remained a cultural touchstone ever since
"Footloose" turns out to be a sort of Boy Scout version of "Flashdance," a carefully toned-down, overly respectable piece of schmaltz ...
Kevin Bacon moves like a machete chopping through the jungle.
I will always be grateful for the way this film has positively impacted my life.

There are so many good things in Frantic that one feels irritated the movie as a whole isn't better than it is. It's certainly miles better than Polanski's most recent effort, the disastrous Pirates, but not as good as it should be.
A cute little concoction for mothers and daughters.
The film is filled with sight gags and features a wonderful performance by Harris.
Now Barbara Harris and Jodie Foster think to themselves in each other's voices and talk in their own, which is better than being either Dean Jones or a dog, but not much.
Scar-eeee!
Tom Holland's directorial debut is a wildly entertaining concoction that perfectly blends horror and comedy. Roddy McDowall steals the show as TV horror host Peter Vincent.
A minor classic of the genre, this is a memorable addition to the vampire tradition in the horror film.

Fright Night benefits from being one of the purest versions of horror-comedy. Both genres are equally represented without manipulation. The tropes of both combine to present real laughs with the terror and real terror with the laughs.

There's no real "action" to speak of, aside from a few fistfights and the third act bombing attack, but From Here to Eternity sure isn't boring.
Terrific performances from Montgomery Clift and Burt Lancaster highlight this limitedly involving romance.
Despite sliding into melodrama a bit too often, From Here to Eternity remains a decent film due to the strong performances of its Oscar-nominated cast.
Fred Zinnemann's strength as a director was less on the technical side and more in line with coaxing stellar performances out of his actors, and with this film, he drew a royal flush.
He is single and bored. She is married and unhappy. Yep, this going to end well. And that's not even factoring in the Japanese are about to bomb the joint at any minute.

From Here to Eternity is the kind of old-school Hollywood melodrama that you can't help but fall for. And while it only occasionally hits greatness, the performances by the cast are as iconic as they come.

Funny Farm is one of those small miracles that starts out like a lot of other movies and then somehow finds its own way, step after step, to an original comic vision.
